greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of ways to express the integer n as a product of its unitary divisors (A034444).
comment: Equivalently, a(n) is the number of ways to express the cyclic group Z_n as a direct sum of its Hall subgroups.  A Hall subgroup of a finite group G is a subgroup whose order is coprime to its index.
a(n) is the number of ways to partition the set of distinct prime factors of n.
Also the number of singleton or pairwise coprime factorizations of n. - _Gus Wiseman_, Sep 24 2019
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..20000
Index entries for sequences computed from exponents in factorization of n
example: For n = 36, its unitary divisors are 1, 4, 9, 36. From these we obtain 36 either as 1*36 or 4*9, thus a(36) = 2. - _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 21 2017
program: (PARI) a(n) = my(t=omega(n), x='x, m=contfracpnqn(matrix(2, t\2, y, z, if( y==1, -z*x^2, 1 - (z+1)*x)))); polcoeff(1/(1 - x + m[2, 1]/m[1, 1]) + O(x^(t+1)), t) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jun 30 2017
xref: Differs from A050320 for the first time at n=36.
- Constant or distinct factors coprime: A327399
results.author: _Geoffrey Critzer_, Jul 09 2015
